comments.commentBody: I like your perception of we are in a 'rent war era', with Congress holding the keys.  Since Obama does not feel he has any obligation to honor the Constitution on anything, foreign or domestic, no need to worry.  He will just do what he wants, when he wants it.

@ Patrice Ayme

Please revisit the facts of 1939/40; Lend Lease was an immense help to the British, our industries had already moved to wartime production, there was a vast increase in military preparedness and FDR cautiously and thoroughly prepared for the inevitable. The US public were unenthusiastic of foreign entanglements; it took Pearl Harbor and the German Nazi declaration of war on 12/12/1941 to galvanize the nation.

The current crisis is anything but "not interesting"; it is not in the interests of the US to become involved in a religious civil war. Should President Obama conclude that he has the power to do what you advocate without the advise and consent of the US Congress the political damage he will garner will be difficult to overcome.

If a foreign power lobbed their version of Tomahawk missiles into NYC, would you consider it an act of war ? If the US fires missiles into Syria, you may be absolutely certain that it would be an act of war.

Agreed, in many of your points. My only problem with this is that our Congress will more than likely vote to GO to war, not to stop one. Nice idea that they might, but really, how many defense contractors are just itching for "another one"?

I guess the "rush" is that people are indeed dying, innocent people, once again. This is nothing new, but there is also pressure on the US to be the "good guys" here and intervene.

But I have to say, I am on board with not rushing in this time.

And really, you gotta LOVE the hypocrisy of Boner, asking Obama how he will "pay for the war", when that question was never asked of GWB and when costs were even mentioned, blatant lies about that were told and believed by all of us, revealing also our stunning lack of critical thinking skills in beating the drums for war. And just how easily lead we are by our rapacious military industrial complex.

This editorial has asked many of the most important questions which must be addressed by President Obama prior to any decision to involving the US in Syria.

Since Syria poses no threat to the US at this moment, and the US has no vital interests in Syria, why is there any need to become involved in Syria ?

The religious civil war in Syria is the latest iteration of the ancient Sunni Vs Shia struggle in the Islamic world. The Saudis and their Gulf neighbors, support the "Rebels", which includes Al Queada fighters from many countries on the Sunni side in conflict with the Shia and Alawites led by President Assad, supported by Hezbolla, Iran and Russia. This toxic mixture is the perfect brew to present the world with yet another Guns of August scenario and the prescription to kick off WWIII.

That the British at Westminster in Parliament today put the brakes on Prime Minister Cameron, supported this time by Chancellor Merkel of Germany, is excellent news. That the French led by President Hollande are debating in their Parliament their intention to go to war is frankly amazing; when they needed to transport The Foreign Legion to Mali recently they had to rent USAF C130's since they did not have the capability to move their troops.

Given the facts of the case, being investigated by the UN, as you noted above, what is the rush ?

President Obama has a Constitutional obligation to ensure that Congress deliberate on this matter and decide what action to take. He must comply.

Christopher Yaun-

"Both Colorado and NOAA agree 3mm SLR for short term. Note the acceleration."

According to a report prepared in June 2012 by NOAA, NESDIS, STAR, SOCD and LSA, the first successful closure of the SLR budget using GRACE, Jason 1,2 and Argo gives 1.2 +/-0.9 or 1.6 +/-0.8 mm/yr over the period Jan 2005 - Dec 2011.
The steric portion of sea level rise has vanished, 0.2 +/-0.8 mm/year.

Note the deceleration.

http://ibis.grdl.noaa.gov/SAT/SeaLevelRise/documents/NOAA_NESDIS_Sea_Lev...
Geo. Washington was a moderate who took up arms.
Interesting! But you left out West Point. We mustn't kid ourselves about the power of the Pentagon and of the "security" industry in general.

Lots of Syrians are being killed, so lets kill a few more Syrians?

There are no Syrian "moderates". Moderates don't take up arms. Moderates all made their peace with Assad and went on with their lives. This has always been a Sunni lead revolution funded by the Sunni gulf states and carried out by Sunni militants.

What we can do is to begin the process of creating an alternative to our own incompetent ruling elite and then organizing our own revolution. So long as our only choices are which of the Yale/Harvard crowd will run the country, we are doomed to failure.
The early week puzzles I  do in ink (my preferred method).  I have learned  that the later week puzzles can be "puzzling" and I don't have the confidence for a pen.

To Leapy and other interested parties:

Since you asked -- obviously you can't buy poisoned entrails in Manhattan. You have to buy the entrails and poison them yourself!

Sheesh, do I have to explain *everything*?
spenyc:  That's just offal.
Okay, okay, I'll get rid of the pen and switch to pencil/eraser.  You convinced me.

Counterfactual history can be fun. Had Federer been 5 years older, perhaps Sampras might not have made it to 14 Slam titles, or Agassi to 8. Had Federer been 5 years younger, he might have added a two-handed backhand able to handle Nadal's ad-court serves.

Keeping score provides objectivity for a given moment in time; comparisons between eras are inherently subjective... and silly. And fun.

If people didn't think this was coming, they are blind to major changes in our economy. It won't change for awhile. With the hourly rate declining, people are working less. they money just isn't there to get into the houses now. Renting is here to stay until the economy changes and people have more money to buy a house. Rental prices have skyrocketed since 2008; there will come a tipping point where renters will get sick of paying such high rent, and the banks will relax a little on requirements to buy a house, and we will get to an even keel or maybe, just maybe more people will want to buy and the real estate investors will be forced to sell or take a reduced payment for rent.

It's a very bad idea for a tenant to enter into a lease option. Tenants rarely purchase the property because (a)they have credit or income problems that rent payments won't solve and/or (b)the purchase price the tenant agreed to pay is more than the house is worth. It's very difficult to determine whether the price is going to be a good or bad deal two years from now, and a large number don't appraise for the agreed price.

And it's often the case that owners who are about to go into foreclosure rent on a lease option. They collect the upfront payment and the increased rental payments, and then allow the house to go into foreclosure. Bad, bad idea.
There was one house on my block where the tenants started out trying to do that.  Then they realized how bad the roof and foundation really were, and they gave up and moved.

The solution to the mortgage backed securities (MBS) bust was to put people into homes on Lease-Option, so that renters would be able to clean up their credit, maintain the vacant properties in hopes of becoming an owner, and become part of the community.

Instead, the banksters were paid for their losses, the properties were sold via the REO loan servicing departments mostly to speculators who used all cash deals, at 60% of market value, with 10 day close of escrow, against prospective owner families with only 3.5% down for 95% of market value and 30 day close. The speculators then hired a couple guys in the Home Depot parking lot who spent 2-3 days putting on a bit of paint and perhaps some new cabinets or carpets, then put these homes into rental inventory.

The property values of these neighborhoods will take a very long time to recover - 10-15 years in the Central Valley from Marysville to Bakersfield.

The speculators literally are their own worst enemy. They could make money by setting up lease options so the neighborhoods improve, enabling everyone to benefit from the increased equity. Instead, these are deteriorating neighborhoods that are becoming crime ridden. Business acquaintances of mine with rentals are discovering the neighbor is a marijuana grow house. And that was one of the appealing quiet neighbors!

In the past lease options had a very low conversion to ownership - as little as 1%. That has to change if we're not going to have a nation of Pottervilles.

I wouldn't wash a rental car that I drive for a few days.  But I would wash a leased car that I'm driving for 3 years.  A residential rental lease typically has a 1-yr minimum.  I get your point, but I still find it overly flippant to compare a rented house to a rented car.

Indeed, Urb.

Seeing that duo was Skilling me softly. But having ENRON caught between 41 & 46D might teach someone a lesson.

Leapy:

You should catch some flack for that comment.

Dizzying, and I have to get up OILY tomorrow. HONEY DEW me a favor and get me the dramamine. AIG and ENRON on the same grid is more than I can bear.

Teews smaerd,

Urb

I see a bit of silver lining.  For one, a higher turnover of neighbors does mean I meet people that I otherwise might never meet in my life.  I bet most of these people are just striving for a decent live.  Won't be bad to expand my horizon.  Longer term, it's easier to pursue work opportunity when I don't have to buy a house.  That's probably true for most people.

How long did they rent the car? I've rented cars for 6 - 8 months and I've washed and cleaned them repeatedly.
Your logic is not logical. The problem is the landlords, who are of the corporate and disconnected variety. They stay at arms length and just do what they have to to collect the rent. For them, it's tenement housing in the 'burbs. It is they who do not care. While a house renter may have more responsibilities than an apartment renter, there still are many instances where it is the landlord's (i.e.: owners) responsibility to maintain the property; and that is what leases are for. If the renters aren't joining the neighborhood watch, maybe they haven't been invited. Maybe Mrs. Holcomb could walk across the street and say "Hi, I have a million hostas, would you like some? And by the way it looks like the Osbornes lawn has been nicely mowed.

I don't look down on renters - it actually can be beneficial financially in the long run for some people -- but I do look down on people who bring a criminal element to my neighborhood; oddly it's only the renters who seem to have to call the police on their own boyfriends, or who get CPS called on them, or nailed for drug dealing, or their cars towed, or whose guests lurk up and down the sidewalks at 2 a.m. smoking cigarettes and drinking beer.

(I have nothing against cigs and booze, or mild drugs for that matter, but having some strange guy creeping around 20 feet from my windows in the middle of the night, talking furtively on a cell phone, is a bit disconcerting relative to what we are used to in this neighborhood.)

I see the point of this article, but I think it oversimplifies things to be attractive to the homeowner audience. I’m a “well-heeled” renter who chooses to rent to stay mobile. If a company calls me up and offers substantial money for me to relocate closer to them, I’m not above packing up and moving. I don’t aspire to homeownership, but do aspire to retire in my mid-40s and am working towards that goal. Renting and staying mobile is facilitating that for me.

That said, I’ll live in a neighborhood below my means, and have done so many times. I’ve lived in rental and “owned” communities and have always been treated as an outsider. Having spent a lot of time in major North American cities, I’ve learned the socially-acceptable ways to ignore people while going about my daily business (NYC'ers know what I mean), and accept the consequences if you expect me to come introduce myself when I move in and I do not do so.

One of the differentiators between me and my neighbors is that I’m happy to be friendly and outgoing to those who take the time to welcome me to the neighborhood, but I’m also an introvert and will not feel bad if I “fail” to introduce myself to my neighbors. If you're my neighbor, approach me when I’m outside. I’m awkward at small-talk, but anticipate that I have the same, common goals you do in regards to our neighborhood and will make the effort. I lose little sleep when “owners” in my chosen neighborhoods look down on me because I’m a renter.
As painful as it is, it is good to see the (truly anecdotal) truth about the assumed moral "superiority" of people who are paying mortgages put out there for all to see.

This story on renters is disturbing. As though the renters are to blame for Laura Halcomb's lack of social skills, and apparently lack of civil consciouseness as well. If Laura wants to meet her neightbors maybe she should grow-up and assume responsibility for walking over to the other's place and saying hello. And the idea that renters are responsible for improper maintenance and/or upkeep of the house, rather than the absentee owner who owns the house for one reason and one reason only, is absurd. Renter's are people too and the property owners need to count their blessings.
That is great you know these two guys who do that. But it's naive to believe they are the rule, as they are the exception.

I know two guys who have been in separate businesses of buying, rehabbing and renting out houses for several years. They have improved their houses and keep them maintained in good condition in order to protect investment, including mowing and edging yards as needed. They want to get and retain good tenants, and their intention is to sell the houses eventually, so they have good incentive to keep the houses in good condition. I believe their 'neighbors' who live in their own homes are lucky these guys bought these houses rather than having the houses sit empty, and I know the municipalities involved are glad to have the up tax assessments and payments kept up. Maybe some of the people who are resentful of rential neighbors should try to be neighborly.

third.coast
earth
"...You said it yourself...renters are slackers."

I was being facetious... "Renters" (like home owners) come in a wide variety. My complaint is with the stereotype and the greed of some of our elite "class".

Wow, i had no idea that renters generate more trash than property owners, I would have assumed the other way around. The arrogant property owners deserve careless renters and the caring property owners deserve renters who care.Your simple calculation on life is all about the price of real estate for the owners, what a simple perspective indeed. And sad.
Wow, lots of assuming here. Our neighborhood is mixed owner occupied & renter occupied. We're thriving, together.

Its really simple - its a case of the have and have nots. Simply put some renters should not own as they do not want a stake in the neighborhood while homeowners generally do but maybe not all the time but they have invested no argument there.  Some HOAs have restrictions on the amount of rentals given in their HOA area but they are hard to enforce that percentage for the most part. On the other hand too many renters and the property valuation goes down along with the increase in trash, noise, crime and general 'don't care attitude'.  To own a home and take care of its maintenance takes money and time and some just barely do.  As a renter (not I) they have less inclination in their stake in the hood. Just that simple.

Jon W, you did realize that the most conservative states receive more in federal benefits than they pay in taxes, don't you? The federal government would save approximately $1.2 billion if Missouri both provided no revenue, nor received any benefits from the feds.

Already thought about it, and I'm thrilled actually. In 2012, Missouri received $1.32 from the Feds for every $1.00 it paid in taxes (in $millions per capita). I'd be thrilled to keep that 32 cents that would result from the wash between what we lose ($1) by Missouri no longer contributing and what we would normally give them (-$1).

They can keep that $1 that's obviously insufficient to cover their current needs and use it to do any number of things currently handled by the Feds, for example:

*create their own currency
*provide for their own defense (military)
*build/repair their own infrastructure (roads, bridges, hospitals, etc.)
*provide their own emergency management (floods, tornadoes, etc.)
*institute their own retirement plan (replace Social Security, Medicare)
*care/support their indigent

Of course, their tax base would continue to deteriorate as their young people left the state to go to college and never return, or left to find jobs currently found in the public sector.

How soon can you guys leave?
You do realize that the majority of  red  states are net "takers" - they receive more federal money than they give back in taxes.

It is sad when I see what we are heading to. We still have not rid ourselves of this "Wild West" attitude. When I read about some of these southern states and some in the midwest, it is scary how what I see is hatred and violence in their minds. Paranoid that someone is taking away their hunting guns, their freedom?. We talk about modern semi-automatics. OUr founding fathers never had any idea how dangerous the weapons have become. Why are they soo afraid to register a gun anyway. It is pathetic really. Yet scary when one thinks how dangerous. I have grandchildren, and I would not want them to even play with a weapon, nor see them go into an army to get killed, for what? For whom? In who's interest?
What is your evidence that everyone of the founders was armed at all times? What does this even mean?

Interesting that the NYT is taking up the issue of state's rights and nullification. The long arm of history shows us that the swing to a federal empire began with the actions of *Jefferson* with the Louisiana Purchase. Ironically, he also wrote the Kentucky Resolutions, which enabled the states to stand up to government tyranny with the Alien and Sedition Acts.

The issue in the states is about self-determination. Whether is is blue states wanting to put an end to the beyond tragic "war on drug users" (which just raises the price and ruins lives in other ways than the drugs do), or more traditional (I hate the word conservative) cultures and states wanting to preserve their rights to self defense. Perhaps the founders did not mention it because they considered it so obvious. Every one of them was armed at most times. In the end, it's the same impulse, self-determination. The Socialist Federals are fighting against self-determination.

The arch of history after Lincoln and the rise of the industrial revolution has been towards centralized control. That's the goal. That's the objective. Thomas Aquinas, the ground-breaking Catholic theologian and scholar, said basically that "the pursuit of the perfection of man, while bringing benefit, always winds up costing more in the end."

The socialist direction of The West since the mid to late 19th century has reached its apex, and we find ourselves sensing that with all that perfection pursued, much has been lost.
Since when? That flies in the face of the Constitution which allows for mullification.
Woody, just where in the Constitution are the states given the power to nullify laws? In the Supremacy clause? In the 14th Amendment? Just where is it?
The "limits" are very clear: states have NO power to nullify federal laws.

The Confederacy of the 21st century doesn't look all
that different from the one of the 19nth or the South
from the 20th, except for the fact that it is made up of republicans.

Or treat it as an act of rebellion and declare martial law in Missouri.

That's what Andrew Jackson was going to do in South Carolina when they tried to nullify federal laws. South Carolina backed down, which was good for them because Jackson wasn't bluffing.

No states have attempted to nullify federal narcotics laws. A few states have simply declined to participate in enforcing those laws. The feds still can, and do, arrest people for possession, use and sale of marijuana in states where it's been partially or completely legalized at the state level.
The NRA is not coming out in favor of this bill. They know how stupid it is, and are keeping their distance.
